{{Infobox court case |name = Pearson v. Chung |court = [[Superior Court of the District of Columbia]] |image = |date decided = {{start date|2007|6|25}} |full name = Roy L. Pearson, Jr. v.Soo Chung, et al. |citations = no. CA-4302-05 (Sup. Ct. D.C. June 25, 2007) |number of judges = 1 |judges = Judith Bartnoff |prior actions = |subsequent actions = ''Pearson v. Chung, et al.'', no. 07-CV-872 (D.C. App. Dec. 18, 2008) |opinions = }} {{Italic title|force=true}} '''''Pearson v. Chung''''', better known as the "'''pants lawsuit''',"<ref>Paul Courson {{cite news|first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Judge in pants lawsuit sues to get job back |url=http://articles.cnn.com/2008-05-02/us/pants.lawsuit_1_compensatory-damages-dry-cleaning-business-judge?_s=PM:US |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=2008-05-02 |accessdate=2011-04-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110824180414/http://articles.cnn.com/2008-05-02/us/pants.lawsuit_1_compensatory-damages-dry-cleaning-business-judge?_s=PM%3AUS |archivedate=August 24, 2011 |df= }}</ref> is a civil case filed in 2005 by Roy L. Pearson, Jr., at the time an [[administrative law judge]], in the [[District of Columbia]] in the [[United States]], following a dispute with a dry cleaning company over a lost pair of trousers. Pearson filed suit against Soo Chung, Jin Nam Chung, and Ki Y. Chung, the owners of Custom Cleaners in [[Washington, D.C.]], initially demanding $67 million for inconvenience, mental anguish, and attorney's fees for representing himself, as a result of their failure, in Pearson's opinion, to live up to a "satisfaction guaranteed" sign that was displayed in the store. The case drew international attention<ref name="APJul9">Lubna Takruri, [http://www.law.com/jsp/article.jsp?id=1183712794216&rss=newswire "Judge Who Lost $54M Suit Not Giving Up Pants Fight"], [[Associated Press]], 2007-07-09 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930183526/http://www.law.com/jsp/article.jsp?id=1183712794216&rss=newswire |date=September 30, 2007 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | publisher = World News Australia | title = Drycleaners win 'pants' suit | url = http://www.worldnewsaustralia.com.au/region.php?id=137947&region=4 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070730202302/http://www.worldnewsaustralia.com.au/region.php?id=137947&region=4 | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 2007-07-30 | accessdate = 2007-07-22}}</ref> when it went to trial in 2007, and has been held up as an example of [[frivolous litigation]] and the need for [[Tort reform#Tort reform in the United States|tort reform in the United States]].<ref>[[American Tort Reform Association]], [http://www.atra.org/newsroom/releases.php?id=8132 press release], 2007-06-25 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070706072427/http://www.atra.org/newsroom/releases.php?id=8132 |date=July 6, 2007 }}</ref>
== Lawsuit == Pearson sued a D.C. [[dry cleaning]] establishment, Custom Cleaners, for over $67 million for the loss of a pair of pants. On May 3, 2005, Pearson allegedly left a pair of gray pants that could be distinguished by a unique trio of belt loops on both sides of the front waistband. After a delay due to the pants being mistakenly sent to another dry cleaners, the pants were offered back completed several days after May 5, 2005, the initial pickup date. Pearson refused to accept the pants, claiming they were not his, despite confirmation by the cleaners' records, tags, and Pearson's receipt. Pearson demanded what he claimed to be the price of the pants as compensation, an amount of over $1000, which the Chungs refused. As a result, Pearson filed suit in the [[Superior Court of the District of Columbia|District of Columbia's Superior Court]]. The judge to whom the case was presented decided to bring it to trial on the basis of two of Pearson's claims. The first claim was the issue of the ownership by Pearson of the presented pair of pants. The second claim was on the issue of signs posted outside the business, advertising "Same Day Service" and "Satisfaction Guaranteed," which Pearson claimed to be misleading.<ref name='Manning Sossamon'>{{cite news|last=Manning |first=Christopher |publisher=Manning Sossamon |title=The Facts of Pearson V. Chung |url=http://manning-sossamon.com/pantfacts/ |accessdate=2009-04-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090515122156/http://manning-sossamon.com/pantfacts/ |archivedate=May 15, 2009 }}</ref>
Over time, the Chungs presented three settlement offers in the amounts of $3000, $4600, and $12,000—all of which were rejected by Pearson. [[Superior Court of the District of Columbia|D.C. Superior Court]] Judge Neal Kravitz stated that "the court has significant concerns that the plaintiff is acting in [[Bad faith#In law|bad faith]]." The judge resolved some of the issues in the Chungs' favor in response to their [[Summary judgment#United States|motion for summary judgment]] (which was filed at the close of [[Discovery (law)|discovery]]), but could not dismiss the case because some facts were in dispute.
The owners of the business, [[South Korea]]n immigrants Jin Nam Chung, Soo Chung, and their son, Ki Chung, were reportedly considering moving back to South Korea.<ref name=lawsuit>{{cite news |last=[[Associated Press]] |title=54 million dollars lawsuit against South Korean dry cleaner over pair of trousers is in full swing |url=http://english.pravda.ru/news/world/21-06-2007/93815-lawsuit-0/ |accessdate=June 30, 2016 |newspaper=pravda.ru |date=21 June 2007}}</ref> After an outpouring of support for the Chungs from members of the public, a website was set up to accept donations for the Chungs' legal defense.<ref name=defensefund>{{cite web|title=Custom Cleaners Defense Fund |url=http://www.customcleanersdefensefund.com/ |accessdate=2007-06-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070605221200/http://www.customcleanersdefensefund.com/ |archivedate=June 5, 2007 }}</ref>
On May 30, 2007, Pearson reduced his demands to $54 million in damages rather than $67 million. Among his requests were $500,000 in attorney's fees, $2 million for "discomfort, inconvenience, and [[Negligent infliction of emotional distress|mental distress]]," and $15,000, which he claimed would be the cost to rent a car every weekend to drive to another dry cleaning service. The remaining $51.5 million would be used to help similarly dissatisfied D.C. consumers sue businesses.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/06/13/AR2007061302033.html |title=Wearing Down the Judicial System with a Pair of Pants |date=June 14, 2007 |accessdate=June 30, 2016 |publisher=[[The Washington Post]] |first=Marc |last=Fisher}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://blog.washingtonpost.com/rawfisher/2007/06/pants_extra_inside_the_courtro.html |title=Pants Extra: Inside the Courtroom |date=June 14, 2007 |accessdate=2007-06-14 |publisher=[[The Washington Post]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080511221852/http://blog.washingtonpost.com/rawfisher/2007/06/pants_extra_inside_the_courtro.html |archivedate=May 11, 2008 }}</ref> Pearson also re-focused his lawsuit from the missing pants to the removal of window signs for "Satisfaction Guaranteed" and "Same Day Service." Pearson claimed the signs represented [[Fraud#United States|fraud]] on the part of the Chungs. The Chungs' lawyer, Christopher Manning, alleged that the signs could only be considered fraud if a [[reasonable person]] would be misled by them, and that a reasonable person would not see the signs as an unconditional promise. The Chungs' lawyer portrayed Pearson as a bitter, financially insolvent man; under questioning, Pearson admitted that, at the start of the court case, he had only $1000–2000 in the bank due to divorce proceedings, and was collecting unemployment benefits.
=== Trial === On June 12, 2007, the trial began. Pearson broke down in tears during an explanation about his frustration after losing his pants,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/discussion/2007/06/14/DI2007061401447.html |title=Pants Lawsuit |date=June 15, 2007 |accessdate=June 30, 2016 |publisher=[[The Washington Post]] |first=Emil |last=Steiner}}</ref> and a short recess had to be declared.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/06/12/AR2007061201667.html?hpid=moreheadlines |title=Judge Who Seeks Millions for Lost Pants Has His (Emotional) Day in Court |date=June 13, 2007 |accessdate=June 30, 2016 |quote=Before trial began yesterday in the case of the D.C. judge who sued his neighborhood dry cleaners after they lost his pants, the most extraordinary fact was Roy Pearson's demand for $65 million in damages. That was before Pearson, an administrative law judge, broke down while testifying about the emotional pain of having the cleaners give him the wrong pants. It was before an 89-year-old woman in a wheelchair told of being chased out of the cleaners by an angry owner. And it was before she compared the owners of Custom Cleaners in open court to Nazis. |publisher=[[The Washington Post]] |first=Marc |last=Fisher}}</ref>
=== Decision === On June 25, 2007, the trial ended with District of Columbia Superior Court Judge Judith Bartnoff ruling in favor of the dry cleaners, and awarding them [[court costs]] pursuant to a [[motion (legal)|motion]] which the Chungs later withdrew.<ref>{{cite news|title=Administrative Law Judge Loses $54 Million Pants Lawsuit |quote=A D.C. Superior Court judge has sided with the defendants in a $54 million lawsuit over a pair of pants. According to the judge's decision, the plaintiff, administrative law Judge Roy Pearson Jr., will take nothing from Soo Chung and Jim Nam Chung, the owners of Custom Cleaners. |publisher=[[NBC]] |url=http://www.nbc4.com/news/13561404/detail.html?treets=dc&tml=dc_break&ts=T&tmi=dc_break_1_09230306252007 |work=NBC4 |accessdate=2007-06-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070629235540/http://www.nbc4.com/news/13561404/detail.html?treets=dc&tml=dc_break&ts=T&tmi=dc_break_1_09230306252007 |archivedate=June 29, 2007 }}</ref> The court took [[judicial notice]] of Pearson's divorce proceedings, where he was sanctioned $12,000 by the trial court for "creating unnecessary litigation and threatening both his wife, Rhonda VanLowe, and her lawyer with disbarment."<ref>[http://www.law.com/jsp/article.jsp?id=1179260861714 Law.com - Ethics Complaint Filed Against Judge Over His $65M Suit Against Dry Cleaners<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930210106/http://www.law.com/jsp/article.jsp?id=1179260861714 |date=September 30, 2007 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=MEMORANDUM OPINION∗ BY CHIEF JUDGE JOHANNA L. FITZPATRICK |url=http://www.courts.state.va.us/opinions/opncavwp/0561044.pdf |date=March 8, 2005 |publisher=COURT OF APPEALS OF VIRGINIA |accessdate=June 30, 2016}}</ref>
=== Post-trial motions and appeal === Pearson made a motion on July 11, 2007, to reconsider in the trial court, stating that he felt the judge had "committed a [[Coram nobis|fundamental legal error]]," and had failed to address his legal claims.<ref name="CBC712">{{cite news |publisher=CBC.CA | title=Customer pursues $54M lawsuit against dry cleaners |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/customer-pursues-54m-lawsuit-against-dry-cleaners-1.677215 |date=2007-07-12 |accessdate=June 30, 2016 |work=CBC News}}</ref> Pearson stated he believed the court had imposed its own conditional interpretation of "satisfaction guaranteed," rather than what Pearson believes is an offer of unconditional and unambiguous satisfaction. The court denied the motion.<ref>[http://www.wusa9.com/news/news_article.aspx?storyid=60842 WUSA9.com | Washington, DC | Judge Refuses To Reconsider Ruling In Pants Case<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927203608/http://www.wusa9.com/news/news_article.aspx?storyid=60842 |date=September 27, 2007 }}</ref>
It was revealed on August 2, 2007 that a panel recommended Pearson not be given a ten-year term as an administrative law judge after his initial two-year term expired mid-2007, in part because his suit against Mr. Chung demonstrated a lack of "judicial temperament." Pearson was appointed in 2005 and stood to lose his $100,512 salary if a hearing upheld that decision.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://blog.washingtonpost.com/rawfisher/2007/08/first_pants_man_loses_case_nex.html |title=First, Pants Man Loses Case. Next, His Job. |first=Marc |last=Fisher |publisher=Washington Post |accessdate=2007-08-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110523081918/http://blog.washingtonpost.com/rawfisher/2007/08/first_pants_man_loses_case_nex.html |archivedate=May 23, 2011 }}</ref> On October 22, a D.C. commission voted against reappointing Pearson to the bench of the Office of Administrative Hearings.<ref>{{cite news |title=Judge Set to Lose Job, Sources Say |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/10/22/AR2007102202170.html?hpid=moreheadlines |publisher=[[Washington Post]] |date=October 23, 2007 |first=Keith L. |last=Alexander |accessdate=June 30, 2016}}</ref> On November 14, it was confirmed that Pearson had lost his job by not being affirmed for an extension.<ref>{{cite news |title=Judge loses more than pants in lawsuit |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20071114/ap_on_fe_st/odd_67_million_pants;_ylt=AsBCsFWuBp0r5ONmYww_dogsQE4F |publisher=[[Associated Press]] |date=November 14, 2007}}{{dead link |date=June 2016}}</ref>
Roy Pearson filed suit against Washington, D.C. on May 2, 2008, claiming that he had been wrongfully dismissed for exposing corruption within the Office of Administrative Hearings. Pearson sought $1 million in compensation for lost wages and [[Punitive damages#United States|punitive damages]] as well as his job back.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=[[The Washington Post]] |author=Emil Steiner |title=Roy Pearson's Latest Lawsuit |url=http://blog.washingtonpost.com/offbeat/2008/05/roy_pearson_suing_district_to.html |date=2008-05-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080706044629/http://blog.washingtonpost.com/offbeat/2008/05/roy_pearson_suing_district_to.html |archivedate=July 6, 2008 }}</ref> On July 23, 2009, federal district judge [[Ellen Segal Huvelle]] dismissed Pearson's May 2008 lawsuit, ruling the District of Columbia had not broken the law by declining to reappoint him as an administrative law judge. Pearson had maintained in the suit that the failure to reappoint him to the ten-year term was in part intended as retaliation for his suit against the dry cleaners.<ref>{{cite news |first=Del Quentin |last=Wilber |title=Ex-Judge's Lawsuit Thrown Out |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/story/2009/07/28/ST2009072801193.html |publisher=Washington Post |date=July 29, 2009 |accessdate=June 30, 2016}}</ref> Pearson lost his appeal when the D.C. Circuit ruled against him on May 27, 2010.<ref>{{cite news |first=Nathan |last=Koppel |title="Pants Judge" Roy Pearson Strikes Out in Court |url=https://blogs.wsj.com/law/2010/05/27/pants-judge-roy-pearson-strikes-out-in-court/ |publisher=Wall Street Journal Law Blog |date=May 27, 2010 |accessdate=June 30, 2016}}</ref>
The Chungs moved to recover $83,000 in attorneys' fees and to impose sanctions, but withdrew the motion after recovering their costs through fund-raising. The Chungs stated that they did so in the hopes of persuading Pearson to stop litigating,<ref name=Cauvin>{{cite news |title=Judge Who Filed Suit Plans to Appeal Defeat |author=Henri E. Cauvin |date=2007-08-15 |publisher=Washington Post |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/08/14/AR2007081401080.html |accessdate=June 30, 2016}}</ref> but on August 14, 2007, Pearson filed a notice of appeal.<ref name=Cauvin/>
On September 10, 2008, Pearson filed an appeal to the [[District of Columbia Court of Appeals]], where oral argument was held on October 22, 2008 before a three-judge panel consisting of judges Phyllis Thompson, Noel Anketell Kramer and Michael W. Farrell.<ref name=WP20081218>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/12/18/AR2008121801345.html |title=Appeals Court Rejects Request for New Trial in Pants Case |publisher=Washington Post |date=December 18, 2008 |first=Keith L. |last=Alexander |accessdate=August 30, 2016}}</ref><ref name="appealopinion">''[http://www.dccourts.gov/internet/documents/07-CV-872.PDF Pearson v. Chung, et al] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140116094839/http://www.dccourts.gov/internet/documents/07-CV-872.PDF |date=2014-01-16 }}'', no. 07-CV-872 (D.C. App. Dec. 18, 2008)</ref> Manning represented the Chungs on the appeal ''[[pro bono]]'',<ref>{{cite news|last1=O'Brien|first1=John|title=Former judge not giving up on $54 mil missing pants case|url=http://legalnewsline.com/stories/510520368-former-judge-not-giving-up-on-54-mil-missing-pants-case|accessdate=August 30, 2016|work=Legal NewsLine|date=January 6, 2009}}</ref> and Pearson represented himself [[pro se]].<ref name="appealopinion"/> On December 18, 2008, the panel that heard Pearson's appeal announced that they were rejecting it. According to the ''[[Washington Post]]'', "Pearson has two remaining avenues of appeal left: He could ask the entire nine-judge appellate court to review the case, or ask the [[U.S. Supreme Court]] to weigh in."<ref name=WP20081218/> On January 6, 2009, Pearson filed a petition with the D.C. Court of Appeals, requesting the case be reheard [[en banc]] by the full nine-judge court.<ref>{{cite news |title=Another hearing sought in missing pants case |url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/offbeat/2009-01-06-missing-pants_N.htm |accessdate=August 30, 2016 |work=USA Today |agency=Associated Press |date=January 6, 2009}}</ref><ref name=Urda>{{cite news |last1=Urda |first1=Anne |title=$54M Missing Pants Judge Running Out Of Options |url=http://www.law360.com/articles/89725/54m-missing-pants-judge-running-out-of-options |accessdate=August 30, 2016 |work=Law360 |date=March 3, 2009}}</ref> On March 2, 2009, the appeals court denied the petition.<ref name=Urda/> Pearson's final option was to ask the U.S. Supreme Court to hear the case.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/03/02/AR2009030202782.html |title=Pants Hearing Rejected |work=The Washington Post |date=March 3, 2009 |accessdate=June 30, 2016}}</ref><ref name=Urda/> The 90-day deadline for seeking Supreme Court review elapsed without Pearson filing a petition for ''[[certiorari]]'', bringing the dispute to an end.
== Cultural impact == The unusual circumstances of this case led the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'', the ''[[Washington Post]]'', and dozens of bloggers to refer to it as "The Great American Pants Suit,"<ref name="wpost_01">{{cite news|url=http://blog.washingtonpost.com/editorialist/2007/06/todays_hot_topics_the_courts_r.html |title=Today's Hot Topics |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=2007-06-26 |author=Rob Anderson |accessdate=2011-06-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110523101555/http://blog.washingtonpost.com/editorialist/2007/06/todays_hot_topics_the_courts_r.html |archivedate=May 23, 2011 }}</ref><ref name="wsj_01">{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB118282035117847903?mod=opinion&ojcontent=otep |title=$67 million pants |publisher=The Wall Street Journal |date=2007-06-26 |accessdate=2011-06-25 |subscription=true}}</ref> and to Pearson as "Judge Fancy Pants."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?click_id=29&art_id=nw20070626085830203C566506&set_id=1 |title='Fancy pants' loses wacky lawsuit |work=[[Independent Online (South Africa)|IOL News (iol.co.za)]] |publisher=[[Independent News & Media]] |author=Lubna Takruri ([[Associated Press]]) |date=2007-06-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070628202113/http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=29&art_id=nw20070626085830203C566506 |archivedate=June 28, 2007 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4188/is_20070626/ai_n19324359 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071118152313/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4188/is_20070626/ai_n19324359 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2007-11-18 |title=Judge sides with cleaner in pants suit |publisher=[[Deseret News]] |author=Lubna Takruri ([[Associated Press]]) |date=2007-06-26}}</ref> The case has garnered considerable international attention. [[BBC News]] quoted Chris Manning, attorney for the Chung family, as saying that the experience for the Chungs has become the "American nightmare"—an ironic reference to the [[American Dream]].<ref>{{cite news |title=US man loses $54m trousers claim |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/americas/6238364.stm |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=June 25, 2007 |accessdate=June 30, 2016}}</ref> [[Fortune magazine|''Fortune'' magazine]] listed the case at #37 in its "101 Dumbest Moments in Business" of 2007.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://money.cnn.com/galleries/2007/fortune/0712/gallery.101_dumbest.fortune/37.html |publisher=[[Fortune magazine|Fortune]] |title=101 Dumbest Moments in Business |date=December 19, 2007 |accessdate=June 30, 2016}}</ref> ''[[Cracked.com]]'' listed the case as "Exhibit 1" in its 2008 article "9 Insane Cases that Prove the US Legal System Is Screwed."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cracked.com/article_16358_9-insane-cases-that-prove-us-legal-system-screwed.html?wa_user1=5&wa_user2=History&wa_user3=article&wa_user4=yesincite|title=9 Insane Cases that Prove the US Legal System Is Screwed |publisher=''Cracked.com'' website |author=Luke McKinney |date=2008-06-12 |accessdate=June 30, 2016}}</ref>
On July 24, 2007, the [[American Tort Reform Association]] and the [[Institute for Legal Reform]] of the [[United States Chamber of Commerce]] hosted a fundraiser for the Chungs to help pay their attorneys fees that reported having raised up to $64,000.<ref>[http://www.chungfundraiser.com/ Support the Chungs<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070705124926/http://www.chungfundraiser.com/ |date=July 5, 2007 }}</ref> The Chungs say they have received close to $100,000 from supporters to cover their attorneys' fees and lost business.<ref name=Cauvin/>
On September 19, 2007, citing a loss of revenue and emotional strain from the lawsuit, the Chungs announced they had closed and sold the dry cleaning shop involved in the dispute. The Chungs still owned one additional dry cleaning shop and said they would be focusing their attention and resources on their remaining shop.<ref name="abc_01">{{cite news | url=http://abclocal.go.com/wpvi/story?section=news/national_world&id=5665422 | title= Dry Cleaner in Pants Suit Closes (Associated Press) | date= September 19, 2007 | accessdate= 2011-06-25 | work= Action News 6abc.com | publisher= [[WPVI-TV|WPVI-TV Philadelphia, PA]] }}</ref>
The incident and lawsuit served as a basis for "[[Law & Order (season 18)#Episodes|Bottomless]]," an 18th-season episode of ''[[Law & Order]]'', which aired originally on 16 January 2008.<ref>{{cite web |title=Law & Order: Bottomless |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1031376/?ref_=ttep_ep4 |date=January 16, 2008 |publisher=Internet Movie Database |accessdate=June 30, 2016}}</ref>

'''Peeter Järvelaid''' (born 28 November 1957) is an Estonian legal scholar and historian. Järvelaid is a professor in the [[University of Tallinn]].<ref>http://law.tlu.ee/gb/39</ref> He has developed semiotic and personality-centered research direction, writing hundreds of articles mostly about the European and Estonian legal history and education, published in Estonian, English, German, French, Russian, Latvian, Finnish, Lithuanian and Swedish. Since 2006 his studies have been increasingly concentrated on the international relations in the 20th century, which among others has required intensive archival researches in German and Polish archives. Since 2012 Järvelaid has placed his research emphasis on the German diplomatic missions, with a specific interest in German diplomatic representation in Tallinn.
==Early life and education== Peeter Järvelaid was born in [[Tallinn]] to a military family.<ref>[http://www.virumaateataja.ee/306585/peeter-jarvelaid-jaab-suguvosa-juurte-juurde/ Peeter Järvelaid jääb suguvõsa juurte juurde - Uudised - Virumaa Teataja<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Järvelaid graduated 1981 from the [[University of Tartu]] and received his [[J. D.]] from the Moscow All-Union Correspondence Institute of Law in 1990.<ref name=autogenerated1>[https://www.etis.ee/portaal/isikuCV.aspx?PersonVID=13181&lang=en]</ref>
==Career== Since 1981 he taught in Faculty of Law at the University of Tartu. In 1992 he became full Professor of Estonian legal history and then in 1993 Professor of Estonian legal history. In 1997 the research efforts of Järvelaid received the Fellowship of the [[Alexander von Humboldt Foundation]], which in 1998-2000 and 2012 enabled him to carry out his research activities in the [[Max Planck Institute for European History of Law]] and other reputed German academic centers. He then moved to the [[University Nord]], which later evolved into the Tallinn University Law School in 2010, where he was Professor of Law, Head of Studies and Dean. In 1997-2000, Järvelaid was the advisor to the [[Estonian Ministry of Justice]]; he also has been the Rector of the [[Estonian Academy of Security Sciences]] (2003-2005) and the [[Estonian Maritime Academy]] (2006-2007).<ref name=autogenerated1 />
==Honours== In 2003 Järvelaid received the 1st class of the [[Order of Merit of the Federal Republic of Germany]].
==Editorial publications== Järvelaid is on the editorial board Istoriya gosudarstva i prava (Russia), Osteuropa-Recht (Germany), Latvijas Universitates Zinatnieskie Raksti (Latvian) and Jog, törteneti szemle (Hungary). He is also corresponding member of the Baltic Historical Commission (Baltische Historische Kommission).<ref>[[:et:Peeter Järvelaid]]</ref>
==Selected publications== *''Die Rezeption Kelsens und der Einfluss der Reinen Rechtslehre in Estland. Robert Walter, Clemens Jabloner, Klaus Zeleny (Ed.). Hans Kelsen anderswo - Hans Kelsen abroad: Der Einfluss der Reinen Rechtslehre auf die Rechtstheorie in verschiedenen Ländern, 73 - 88. Hans-Kelsen-Institut - Universität Wien, Austria: Manz'sche Verlags Wien (2010).'' *''Das Frühwerk Ilmar Tammelos: Der Weg zum Wissenschaftler. Raimund Jakob, Lothar Philipps, Erich Schweighofer, Csaba Varga (Ed.). Auf dem Weg zur Idee der Gerechtigkeit. Gedenkschrift für Ilmar Tammelo 5 - 21. Wien-Münster: LIT (2009).'' *''Friedrich Georg von Bunge und Leo Leesment. Ein biographischer Essay. Baltisch-europäische Rechtsgeschichte und Lexikographie 233 - 280. Heidelberg, Heidelberger Akademie der Wissenschaften: Universitätsverlag Winter (2009).'' *''Baltische Rechtswissenschaftsgeschichte: Professor Jüri Uluots (1890-1945) in seiner und unserer zait. Juridiskā zinātne = Law, 740, 73 - 94. (2008).'' *''Europäische Rechtshistoriker des 19. Jahrhunderts Professor Oswald Schmidt - ein Jurist aus Livland, der während des Zeitalters des Nationalismus und nationalen Erwachens Rechtsgeschichte lehrte. Juridiskā zinātne = Law, 61 - 72. (2008).'' *''Kein Staat ohne Staatsmythos. Kalevipoeg – seine staatstragende Gestaltung für Estland. Ein Versuch das Reich Kreutzwalds und Kalevipoegs zu rekonstruieren. Diestelkamp, B. (Ed.). Liber Amicorum Kjell A. Modeer 285 - 294. Lund: Lund University Press (2007).'' *''Baltische Rechtswissenschaftsgeschichte: zwei grenzüberschreitende Rechtshistoriker Friedrich von Bunge und Leo Leesment. Juridiskā zinātne = Law, 99 - 138. Rīga: Latvijas Universitāte: Latvia (2006).'' *''F. G. von Bunge als Professor an der Universität Dorpat/Tartu (1831-1842). In: Õpetatud Eesti Seltsi Toimetised XXXV: Tundmatu Friedrich Georg von Bunge: Materjale Õpetatud Eesti Seltsi konverentsilt 200 aastat prof Friedrich Georg von Bunge (1802-1897) sünnist Tartu Ülikooli ajaloo muuseumis 27. aprillil 2002.., 2006, 70 - 75. (2006).'' *''Kalevipoeg - seine staatstragende Gestaltung für Estland: Versuch, Kalevipoeg durch Kreutzwalds Leben zu rekonstruieren. Kalevipoeg: das estniche Nationalepos, 307 - 314. Stuttgart, Berlin: Berlin: Mayer (2004).'' *''Enlargement of the European Union in the 21-st century - either integration or moving on parallel ways? In: Evaluation of legislation: proceedings of the fourth congress of the European Association of Legislation (EAL): Evaluation of legislatio,n in Warsaw (Poland), 15th-16th 2000. Baden-Baden: European Association of Legislation ; Deutsche Gesellschaft für Gesetzgebung, 2002, 156-169. (2002).'' *''Rolle der Rechtsgeschichte bei der Wiederherstellung der Souveränität der baltischen Staaten in der 90-er Jahren. In: Rättshistoria i föränding. Olinska stiftelsen 50 ar.Ett internationellt symposium i Stockholm den 19–21 November 1997: Legal History in Change. The Olin Foundation for Legal History 50 Years; Stockholm; 19–21 November 1997. Lund: Lund University, 2002, 293 - 302. (2002).'' *''Die Zeit zwischen den Weltkriegen: westliche Vorbilder für die innere Organisation der neuen Staaten? Die baltischen Staaten im Schnittpunkt der Entwicklungen: Vergangenheit und Gegenwart, 133 - 140. Basel: Schwabe Verlag. (2002).'' *''Oikeuskanslerin instituutio Virossa – historiaa ja nykypäivää. Lakimies, 4, 726 - 734. (2001).'' *''Estonian legal culture on the threshold to the 21st century. International Journal of Legal Information, 1, 75 - 83. {{distinguish|Right of abode|Legal residence|Tax residence}} {{For|a similar phrase|Permanent residence (disambiguation){{!}}Permanent residence}} {{More citations needed|date=October 2018}} [[File:2017-us-green-card-specimen.png|thumb|Sample of a 2017 [[lawful permanent residents (United States)|permanent resident card]] (green card) of the [[United States]], which permits its holder to live and work anywhere in the country similar to that of all other [[Americans]]. Before a person is naturalized as a [[citizenship of the United States|U.S. citizen]], they must be a green card holder for at least 5 years and satisfy all other naturalization requirements.<ref name="LPR"/><ref name="Green Card"/>]] '''Permanent residency''' refers to a person's [[residency (domicile)|resident]] status in a country of which they are not a [[citizenship|citizen]]. This is usually for an indefinite period; a person with such status is known as a permanent resident.
Permanent residency itself is distinct from [[right of abode]], which waives immigration control for such persons. Persons having permanent residency still require immigration control if they do not have right of abode. However, a right of abode automatically grants people permanent residency. This status also gives [[work permit]] in most cases.<ref name="LPR"/>
==Countries with permanent residency systems== {{refimprove section|date=July 2009}} Not every country allows permanent residency. Rights and application may vary widely.
All European Union countries have a facility for someone to become a permanent resident, as EU legislation allows an EU national who moves to another EU country to attain permanent resident status after residing there for five years. The European Union also sets out permanent residency rights for [[Long-term resident (European Union)|long-term resident]] third country nationals under directive (2003/109/EC). A novel approach was the granting of rights across the national borders of states adhering to the directive.
Other countries have varying forms of such residency and relationships with other countries with regards to permanent residency.
[[File:Passeport français - Visas japonais-v1.jpg|thumb|Japanese ''permission for permanent residence'' issued in 2011 on a [[French passport]].]] The regions that have some type of permanent resident status include: * [[Argentina]] * [[Australian permanent resident|Australia]] * Bahrain * [[Barbuda]]<ref name="Citizenship by investment">{{cite web|url=https://www.henleyglobal.com/citizenship-by-investment/|title=CITIZENSHIP BY INVESTMENT: Citizenship By Investment Options - Henley & Partners|work=henleyglobal.com}}</ref> * [[Belize]] * [[Brazil]] * [[Brunei Darussalam]] (called ''penduduk tetap'') * [[permanent resident (Canada)|Canada]] (permanent residents were known as ''landed immigrants'' before 28 June 2002) * [[Chile]] * [[People's Republic of China|China (PRC)]] (called 永久居留权 (''yǒngjiǔ-jūliúquán''), programme started from 2004)<ref>For details, see the [http://lawandborder.com/?p=1962 Unofficial translation of the “Administrative Measures for Treatment of Foreigners Residing Permanently in China”], 2012-12-18</ref> * [[Costa Rica]] * [[Dominican Republic]] * [[Ecuador]] * [[European Union]]: ** [[Austria]] (called ''Niederlassungsbewilligung'') - [https://wap.business-standard.com/article/economy-policy/invest-rs-10-cr-be-a-permanent-resident-of-india-116083101327_1.html Descriptions] * [[Iran]]<ref>[http://www.mfa.gov.ir/cms/cms/Tehran/en/ConsularAffairs/pasport/Visa/ResidencePermit.html] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091216102747/http://www.mfa.gov.ir/cms/cms/Tehran/en/ConsularAffairs/pasport/Visa/ResidencePermit.html|date=December 16, 2009}}</ref> * [[Israel]] (The term ''toshàv-kéva'' may refer to a permanent resident without citizenship, or to a citizen with registered abode) * [[Japan]] (called 永住権 ''eijūken'') * [[South Korea]] * [[Macau]] (born to citizens of Macau, but was born outside of Macau.) * [[Macedonia (country)|Macedonia]] * [[Malaysia]] (called ''pemastautin tetap'') * [[Mexico]] * [[Nicaragua]] (called ''Résidents Permanents Nicaragua'') [http://www.amb-nicaragua.fr/zwook/servicesconsulaires/obtenirunvisa/residentsrentiersretraites Descriptions] * [[New Zealand permanent residency|New Zealand]] * [[Norway]] (<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.udi.no/templates/Tema.aspx?id=7427|title=Want to apply: Permanent residence - UDI|work=udi.no}}</ref>) * [[Panama]] <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.migracion.gob.pa/|title=Dirección Nacional de Migración y Naturalización|date=2 January 2007|publisher=|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070102144915/http://www.migracion.gob.pa/|archivedate=2 January 2007|df=}}</ref> * [[Peru]] (A permanent residency option is available for those from countries which prohibit dual citizenship. Permanent residency only requires an annual fee, and no other supporting documents.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20010201085000/http://www.digemin.gob.pe/]</ref>) * [[Philippines]] * [[Russia]] (called "вид на жительство" ''vid na žítel'stvo'', or ПМЖ ''pe-em-žé'') * [[Singapore]] * [[South Africa]] * [[St. Kitts and Nevis]]<ref name="Citizenship by investment"/> * [[Switzerland]] (''Permis d'établissement'' or ''Niederlassungsbewilligung'', commonly referred to as a C permit (Permis C, C-Ausweis) (settlement permit)<ref name=autogenerated1>[http://www.bfm.admin.ch/bfm/en/home/themen/aufenthalt/die_verschiedenen/ausweis_c__niederlassungsbewilligung.html Permit C (settlement permit) – Federal Office for Migration] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071023031800/http://www.bfm.admin.ch/bfm/en/home/themen/aufenthalt/die_verschiedenen/ausweis_c__niederlassungsbewilligung.html |date=October 23, 2007 }}</ref>) * [[Taiwan|Republic of China (Taiwan)]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.immigration.gov.tw/|title=中華民國內政部移民署全球資訊網 NATIONAL IMMIGRATION AGENCY|work=immigration.gov.tw}}</ref> * [[Thailand]] * [http://www.immigration.gov.tt/Services/PermanentResidenceandCitizenship.aspx Trinidad and Tobago] * [[Ukraine]] (called "посвідка на постійне проживання"' 'posvidka na postijne prozhyvannya'', or ППП "pe-pe-pe"). See grounds to obtain [http://en.clc.co.ua/permanent-residency-in-ukraine/ Permanent Residence in Ukraine].'' The easiest way to obtain residence permit in Ukraine is by obtaining a work permit in Ukraine. * [[United States]] ([[lawful permanent residents (United States)|lawfully admitted for permanent residence]]<ref name="LPR"/>)
===Other forms of permanent residency=== * India does not permit dual citizenship, but former Indian citizens, and persons of Indian origin, are eligible to apply for an ''[[Overseas Citizen of India]] (OCI)'' card that allows them to live and work freely in India, apart from running for certain political office posts and occupying constitutional posts. They also cannot vote or buy agricultural land. Spouses who have no other connection to India other than being married to someone with or eligible for OCI can also apply for OCI if they have been married for at least two years. Once the marriage is dissolved, OCI status is automatically lost for spouse with no connection to India. Recently in 2016 India allowed Permanent Resident Status to foreigners with some conditions. * Turkey allows dual citizenship, and former Turkish citizens who have given up their Turkish citizenship (for example, because they have naturalized in a country that usually does not permit dual citizenship, such as Germany, Austria, South Korea or Japan) can apply for the "Blue Card" (''mavi kart''), which gives them some citizens' rights back, e.g. the right to live and work in Turkey, the right to possess land or the right to inherit, but not the right to vote.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}} * Some countries have made '''treaties regulating travel and access to the job markets (non-government/non-military-related work)''': A citizen of an EU country can live and work indefinitely in other EU countries and in Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway, and Switzerland (and citizens of these countries can live and work in EU countries). The [[Trans-Tasman Travel Arrangement]] between Australia and New Zealand allows citizens of the two countries to live and work in the other country. A citizen of a [[Gulf Cooperation Council]] (GCC) member state (Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, and United Arab Emirates) can live and work in other member states.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}} : However, for voting, being voted and working for the public sector or the national security in a country, citizenship of the country concerned is almost always required.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}}
==== Golden Visas ==== A "[[golden visa]]" is a permanent residency visa issued to individuals who invest, often through the purchase of property, a certain sum of money into the issuing county. Dating back to the 1980s, golden visas became much more popular and available in the 21st century. Golden visas require investments of anywhere from $100,000<ref>[http://www.goldenvisas.com/dominica/]</ref> in [[Dominica]] up to £2,000,000 in the U.K.<ref>[http://www.goldenvisas.com/uk/]</ref> The most common method for obtaining a golden visa is through the purchase of real estate with a minimum value.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/ceciliarodriguez/2013/09/29/want-to-live-in-europe-buy-a-residency-permit/ |title=Want To Live In Europe? "Buy" A Residency Permit |website=Forbes.com |date= |accessdate=2016-12-21}}</ref> Some countries such as Malta and Cyprus also offer "[[golden passports]]" (citizenship) to individuals if they invest a certain sum.<ref>Where is the cheapest place to buy citizenship?, By Kim Gittleson BBC reporter, New York, 4 June 2014, https://www.bbc.com/news/business-27674135</ref>
The issuing of so-called "golden visas" has sparked controversy in several countries.<ref>Canada kills investor visa popular with Chinese, by Sophia Yan @sophia_yan March 25, 2014: 2:21 AM ET , CNN, [http://money.cnn.com/2014/02/12/news/canada-chinese-immigration/index.html]</ref><ref>[https://www.economist.com/news/europe/21633854-schemes-effect-sell-visas-rich-foreigners-come-under-fire-buying-their-way Buying their way in, Economist 22 november 2014]</ref>
== Limitations of permanent residents == Depending on the country, permanent residents usually have the same rights as citizens except for the following: * they may not [[vote]] (though in some cases such as the UK's [[Commonwealth citizen]]s, New Zealand and Belgium, voting is allowed) * they may not stand for [[public office]] (except [[European Union]] citizens permanently residing in other EU member states who may stand in local and European elections) * in most cases they may not hold [[public sector]] employment. Canada and New Zealand allow this; some countries, such as Brazil and Portugal, allow it only for permanent residents holding citizenship of another country of [[colonialism|shared heritage]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/decreto/D70391.htm |title=D70391 |website=Planalto.gov.br |date= |accessdate=2016-12-21}}</ref>) * they may not usually apply for employment involving [[national security]]. In Singapore, male PRs who have been granted PR before the age of 18 have to serve [[national service]]. Most first-generation males are exempted. * they may not own certain classes of [[real estate]] * they are not issued the [[passport]] of that country (unless otherwise stateless or unable to obtain a passport from their country of nationality, in which case they may be entitled to a [[certificate of identity]] instead) * they do not have access to the country's [[consul (representative)|consul]]ar protection (some countries such as Australia allow this)<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20111127063444/http://www.smartraveller.gov.au/services/consular-services-charter.html]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nzembassy.com/iran/new-zealanders-overseas/embassy-services-new-zealanders |title=Embassies | New Zealand Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade |website=Nzembassy.com |date= |accessdate=2016-12-21}}</ref> * they may qualify to [[naturalisation|apply for citizenship]] after meeting a specified period of residence
== Obligations of permanent residents == Permanent residents may be required to fulfil specific residence obligations to maintain their status. In some cases, permanent residency may be conditional on a certain type of employment or maintenance of a business.
Many countries have compulsory [[conscription|military service]] for citizens. Some countries, such as Singapore, extend this to permanent residents. However, in Singapore, most first generation permanent residents are exempted, and only their sons are held liable for NS.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.expatexperience.sg/moving-singapore/singapore-permanent-residency |title=Singapore Permanent Residency |work=Expat Experience Singapore |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150215205030/http://www.expatexperience.sg/moving-singapore/singapore-permanent-residency/ |archivedate=2015-02-15 |df= }}</ref>
In a similar approach, the United States has [[Selective Service]], a compulsory ''registration'' for military service, which is required of all male citizens and permanent residents ages 18 to 26; this requirement theoretically applies even to those residing in the country illegally.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sss.gov/QA.HTM#quest7 |title=Selective Service Systems > Home |website=Sss.gov |date= |accessdate=2016-12-21}}</ref> Applications for citizenship may be denied or otherwise impeded if the applicant cannot prove having complied with this requirement.
Permanent residents may be required to reside in the country offering them residence for a given minimum length of time (as in Australia and Canada). Permanent residents may lose their status if they stay outside their host country for more than a specified period of time (as in the United States).
Permanent residents have the same obligations as citizens regarding taxes.
== Loss of status == Permanent residents may lose their status if they fail to comply with [[Residency (domicile)|residency]] or other obligations imposed on them. For example: * they leave the country beyond a maximum number of days (varies among countries but usually more than 2 years) * they become a threat to national security, or they commit serious crimes and become subject to deportation or removal from the country
== Access to citizenship == Usually permanent residents may apply for citizenship by [[naturalization]] after a period of permanent residency (typically five years) in the country concerned. [[Dual citizenship]] may or may not be permitted.
In many nations an application for naturalization can be denied on character grounds, sometimes allowing people to reside in the country (as non-domiciled) but not become citizens. In the United States the residency requirements for citizenship are normally five years, even though permanent residents who have been married to a US citizen for three years or more may apply in three years. Those who have served in the armed forces may qualify for an expedited process allowing citizenship after only one year, or even without any residence requirement.<ref>[https://www.uscis.gov/policymanual/HTML/PolicyManual-Volume12-PartD.html General Naturalization Requirements] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160307173800/https://www.uscis.gov/policymanual/HTML/PolicyManual-Volume12-PartD.html |date=March 7, 2016 }}</ref>
===Golden Passports=== Since the 1990s, in addition to [[golden visa]]s some countries have begun to offer [[golden passport]]s to foreign nationals who invest (often through the purchase of property) a certain sum into the issuing country's economy.<ref>The Oxford Handbook of Citizenship, Ayelet Shachar, Chapter 35, Citizenship For Sale?, pg. 790, Oxford University Press, 2017</ref> The issuing of EU passports by [[Malta]] and [[Cyprus]] has sparked controversy but is expected to produced billions of euros in revenue for the issuing countries.<ref>Malta’s golden passport scheme draws fresh criticism, Concerns centre on selection of Jersey consultancy to run operation targeted at the wealthy, FT.com, https://www.ft.com/content/6f98892e-fbf3-11e5-b3f6-11d5706b613b</ref>
== Automatic entitlement == Full permanent residence rights are granted automatically between the following: * Ireland and the United Kingdom including general election voting rights. * the states of the [[Nordic Council]] * [[Russian Federation]] and [[Republic of Belarus]]
In some cases (e.g., the member states of the [[European Union]]) citizens of participating countries can live and work at will in each other's states, but don't have a status fully equivalent to that of a permanent resident. In particular, under the Trans-Tasman Travel Arrangement, Australia and New Zealand grant each other's citizens the right to reside permanently and work in each country; however, the rights and entitlements of New Zealanders living in Australia under this arrangement (the so-called [[Special Category Visa]]) are somewhat short of those of [[Australian permanent resident]]s, in particular with respect to unemployment benefits and similar benefits.
==Proof of permanent residency== People who are granted permanent residency in a country are usually issued some sort of documentary evidence as legal proof of this status. In the past, many countries merely stamped the person's passport indicating that the holder was admitted as a permanent resident or that he/she was exempt from immigration control and permitted to work without restriction. Other countries would issue a photo ID card, place a visa sticker or certificate of residence in the person's passport, or issue a letter to confirm their permanent resident status.
In Australia and New Zealand, a printout of permanent residence visa or resident visa is stuck to a page of the permanent resident's passport. (On 1 September 2015, Australia ceased issuing visa labels to holders of Australian visas.) <ref>https://www.homeaffairs.gov.au/aboutyourvisa</ref>
In Canada, permanent residents are issued a photo ID card known as Permanent Resident Card.
In Costa Rica, permanent residents are issued a photo ID card commonly referred to as a "cedula".
In the countries of the European Union, [[Residence card (European Union)|residency permits are a photo ID card]] following a common EU design.
In Germany, resident permits ''([[German residence permit|Aufenthaltstitel]])'' have been issued as photo ID cards following a common EU design since 1 September 2011. Prior to that date, residence permits were stickers (similar to visas) which were affixed to the resident's passport.
In Ghana, permanent residents are issued an Indefinite Residence permit which is in the form of a sticker attached into the resident's passport.
In Hong Kong, permanent residents are issued a Hong Kong Permanent Identity Card.
In Japan and South Korea, all resident foreigners are issued a residence card, and for permanent residents this status is indicated.
In Lithuania, permanent residents are issued a photo ID ''(Leidimas gyventi)'' following a common EU design.
In Macau, permanent residents are issued a Macao Permanent Resident Identity Card (''Bilhete de Identidade de Residente Permanente'').
In Malaysia, permanent residents are issued with a [[MyPR]] card similar to the [[MyKad]] issued to Malaysian citizens, the difference being the colour (red instead of blue) and additional information stating the cardholder's country of origin.
In Singapore, permanent residents are issued a blue identity card with their photograph, thumb print and other personal particulars similar to citizen's pink identity card
In Slovakia, permanent residents are issued a red photo ID.
In South Africa, permanent residents who have their passport endorsed, are issued a certificate and a standard national green identity book showing "NON S.A. CITIZEN".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lissa.com/permanent-residence-permit/|title=LISSA Permanent Residence Permit - Legal Migration Services|work=LISSA}}</ref>
In Switzerland, permanent residents are issued either a biometric ID card in accordance with Schengen regulations if they are non EU/EFTA national, or a paper permit in a yellow-coloured plastic wallet if they are an EU/EFTA national.
In Taiwan, permanent residents are issued a blue photo ID card (APRC). A separate open work permit can also be issued to permanent residents allowing them to accept employment in any non-governmental positions for which they are qualified.
In the United Kingdom, the applicant is issued with a photo ID card known as a [[UK Borders Act 2007|Biometric Residence Permit]] which states that the permit is a Settlement permit for Indefinite Leave to Remain.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://contact-ukba.homeoffice.gov.uk/visas-immigration/settlement/ |title=UK Border Agency - Settling in the UK |accessdate=2014-03-07 |publisher=Home Office |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140308033932/https://contact-ukba.homeoffice.gov.uk/visas-immigration/settlement/ |archivedate=2014-03-08 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.narrowboat-waiouru.co.uk/2013/11/no-need-to-hide.html |title=nb Waiouru: No need to hide |accessdate=2014-03-07 |publisher=Thomas Everard Jones}}</ref>
In the United States, permanent residents are non-citizens issued a photo ID card which is officially known as a [[lawful permanent residents (United States)|Permanent Resident Card]], also known as a "green card".<ref name="Green Card">{{cite web |title=Green Card |url=https://www.uscis.gov/greencard |date=February 22, 2018 |accessdate=2018-10-17 |publisher=[[United States Citizenship and Immigration Services|U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services]] (USCIS)}}</ref><ref name="LPR">{{uscsub|8|1101|a|20}} ("The term '[[lawful permanent residents (United States)|lawfully admitted for permanent residence]]' means the status of having been lawfully [[wikt:accord#English|accorded]] the [[wikt:privilege#English|privilege]] of residing [[wikt:permanently#English|permanently]] in the United States as an [[wikt:immigrant#English|immigrant]] ...."); see also {{cite web |title=Lawful Permanent Residents (LPR) |url=https://www.dhs.gov/immigration-statistics/lawful-permanent-residents |date=October 2, 2018 |accessdate=2018-10-17 |publisher=[[United States Department of Homeland Security|U.S. Dept. of Homeland Security]] (DHS)}}</ref>

'''R5''', in the [[film]] business, is a DVD of a movie sold in [[Russia]] much closer after the first screening in cinema, at reduced wholesale prices.<ref name="report" /><ref name="ANTiX" /> It is made with a [[telecine]] machine from an analog source and is typically of a lower quality than other<!--any region--> retail releases.<ref name="paramount" /><!--"studio-produced unmastered telecine"-->
In [[telecine]] (TK)<!-- not a 'TC', but the process of transferring a motion picture film into video--> is the digitization performed by the studio itself with very professional (and expensive) equipment and usually from the original source.<ref name="district9" /><ref name="norman" /> The purpose of it is to create a high quality digital copy (usually for a later [[DVD]] release). But unlike a DVD, an R5 is released before the digital post-processing is finished.<ref name="pukka" /> The quality of the rips can widely differ, but an R5 can be almost indistinguishable from a DVDRip since many unauthorized film copies are published onto DVD with minimal editing.
This digital post-processing is an important step, and provides many qualitative benefits to the finished conversion and should not be under-appreciated. From color correction to grain removal/reduction there are many steps that improve the transfer that generally the R5 does not have, even if done by the originating studio.{{Citation needed|date=May 2012}}<!-- "Minor changes and adds from a Hollywood insider" http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=R5_(bootleg)&diff=next&oldid=399340792 -->
The name R5 refers to [[DVD region code|DVD Region]] 5.<ref name="scenelingo" /> In an effort to compete with [[copyright infringement]] in these areas, the [[movie industry]] chose to create a new format for DVD releases that could be produced more quickly and less expensively than traditional DVD releases.<ref name="report" /><ref name="tvcenter.ru" /> R5 releases differ from normal releases in that they often lack both the image post-processing and special features that are common on DVD releases.<ref name="rlslogmoviesrc" /> This allows the film to be released for sale at the same time that DVD [[Screener (promotional)|screener]]s are released. Since these screeners are the chief source of high-quality pre-DVD release unauthorized film copies (in comparison to [[Cam (bootleg)|cam]] or [[telesync]], mostly), this allows the movie studios to beat the infringers to market.<ref name="paramount" /><ref name="dvdtalk" /> [[Bootleg recording|Bootlegged]] copies of these releases are often distributed on the internet and in some cases, R5 DVDs may be released without an English audio track, requiring the encoder to use the direct line audio from the film's theatrical release. In this case, the unauthorized release will be tagged with "LiNE" to distinguish it from a release with a DVD audio track.<ref name="district9" /><ref name="scenelingo" /><ref name="releasedates" /> Before PUKKA/DREAMLiGHT introduced the R5 tag to the [[warez scene]]<!-- as in they were the first scene group tagging with R5 -->, the R5 releases were tagged as [[Telecine_(piracy)|TC]], [[Screener (promotional)|DVDSCR]] or [[DVD-Rip|DVDRip]].<ref name="pukka" />
The image quality of an R5 release is generally comparable to a DVD Screener release, except without the added scrolling text and black and white scenes that serve to distinguish screeners from commercial DVD releases. R5 quality can be somewhat better than transfers produced by movie bootleggers because the transfer is performed using professional-grade film scanning equipment.{{Citation needed|date=May 2012}}<!--<ref name="paramount" /> "studio-produced unmastered telecine"-->

<ref name="paramount"> {{cite web |url=http://www.rlslog.net/paramount-pictures-r5s/ |title=Paramount Pictures & R5's |author=sc0rff |date=2008-08-06 |work=ReleaseLog |accessdate=2009-12-31 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151128235800/http://www.rlslog.net/paramount-pictures-r5s/ |archivedate=2015-11-28 |deadurl=no |quote=An 'R5' tagged release from the [[Warez scene|scene]] is a studio-produced unmastered telecine, put out quickly and cheaply to compete against telecine piracy in Russia. Mostly they are released with Russian audio only, so scene groups have to source direct English audio. Not all studios are on board for this and so do not release them, [[Paramount Pictures|Paramount]] is one of them.}} </ref>
<ref name="pukka">{{cite web |url=http://www.vcdq.com/sites/default/files/vcdq_nfo_images/23405/79697.png |title=Flyboys.READNFO.R5.XViD-PUKKA |author=PUKKA |date=2006-11-23 |work=VCD Quality |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120314060346/http://www.vcdq.com/sites/default/files/vcdq_nfo_images/23405/79697.png |archivedate=2012-03-14}} First [[Warez scene|scene]] release that introduced the R5 tag. See also [http://www.vcdq.com/files/nfos/16-2010/18643/65124_0.nfo Flyboys.READNFO.R5.DVDR-DREAMLiGHT]. </ref>
<ref name="ANTiX"><!-- Same people as PUKKA? -->{{cite web |title=Flyboys.READNFO.R5.SVCD-ANTiX |author=ANTiX |date=2006-11-23<!--2006-11-23 19:33:21 GMT--> |quote=We agree with Pukka and will be tagging future releases with R5 if it's Russian retail source. Everybody should be able to see the quality of the release in the dir tag, so please stop fake tagging.}} </ref>
<ref name="report">{{cite web |url = http://www.obs.coe.int/oea_publ/eurocine/russianfilmindustry_nevafilm2009.pdf |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110722013622/http://www.obs.coe.int/oea_publ/eurocine/russianfilmindustry_nevafilm2009.pdf |deadurl = no |archivedate = 2011-07-22 |title = The Film Industry in the Federation of Russia |author = Research by Nevafilm, with the collaboration of RFilms (Invest Collegium) for the European Audiovisual Observatory. |date = November 2009 |publisher = European Audiovisual Observatory |location = France |page = 150 |format = PDF |accessdate = 2010-01-21 |quote = During the autumn of 2005 the Hollywood majors [[Warner Home Video]] and [[Universal Studios|Universal Pictures International]] announced their readiness to place special DVD releases on the Russian market at reduced wholesale prices. [...] Simultaneously, the national representatives of the US studios shrank the window for release to video of new films on distribution (special Russian editions were released just four weeks after the first screening in cinemas). }} {{cite web |url=http://www.obs.coe.int/about/oea/pr/russianfilmindustry_nevafilm.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-01-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091222225142/http://www.obs.coe.int/about/oea/pr/russianfilmindustry_nevafilm.html |archivedate=2009-12-22 |df= }} </ref>
<ref name="tvcenter.ru"> {{cite web |url=http://www.tvcenter.ru/all-tv/V-2006-g-prodazhi-licenzionnyh-DVD-v-Rossii-vyrosli-vdvoe-do-42-mln-diskov/ |title=В 2006 г. продажи лицензионных DVD в России выросли вдвое - до 42 млн дисков |trans-title=In 2006, sales of licensed DVD in Russia has doubled - up to 42 million discs |first= |last= |author= |authorlink= |coauthors= |date=2007-01-23 |work=tvcenter.ru |language=Russian |accessdate=2010-01-21 |quote="A positive role was played by distributing releases with a short window (the difference between film premieres and the release on DVD) and the reduction of prices on wheels" - said Trushin. Four weeks after the premiere of a movie on DVD now appear movie studios [[Universal Records|Universal]] and [[20th Century Fox]], explains Dobychin and added that the recommended retail price of a DVD with movies of these studios, as well as [[Sony Pictures]] and Russian producers decreased from 299 to 149 rubles. Prices for DVD studios [[Disney]] and [[Warner Bros.]] did not decrease.}} Same article, other source: [http://www.e-xecutive.ru/news/news/485815/?phrase_id=1505065] Translated: [http://translate.google.be/translate?sl=ru&tl=en&u=http://www.e-xecutive.ru/news/news/485815/%3Fphrase_id%3D1505065] </ref>
<ref name="rlslogmoviesrc"> {{cite web |url=http://www.rlslog.net/movie-sources/ |title=Movie sources |date=2008-08-06 |work=Release Log |accessdate=2009-12-31 |quote=This is fairly new movie format. Basically the same as DVD Screener – this kind of release is legal DVD released in Russia to decrease the level of pirated movies in this country. Retail is rushed out by the studio, so there is little to no cleanup of the film after the telecine process. As a result, you can see some scratches, hairs or other mess on the picture, but you will hardly notice it while watching. External English audio is often used, as these are supplied with Russian sound by default.}} </ref>
<ref name="dvdtalk"> {{cite web |url=http://forum.dvdtalk.com/international-dvd-talk/508251-early-released-russian-dvds-hollywood-films-no-english-audio-options.html#post_message_8053098 |title=Early-released Russian DVDs of Hollywood films: No English audio options? |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716145640/http://forum.dvdtalk.com/international-dvd-talk/508251-early-released-russian-dvds-hollywood-films-no-english-audio-options.html |archivedate=2011-07-16 |deadurl=no |date=2008-08-06 |work=DVD Talk Forum |accessdate=2009-01-19}} Russians explaining the situation in their country. </ref>
<ref name="scenelingo"> {{cite web |url=http://scenelingo.wordpress.com/2008/07/29/what-does-r5-mean/ |title=What does "R5" mean? |date=2008-07-29 |publisher=Scene Lingo |work=Definitions from the "Scene"! |accessdate=2009-12-31}} </ref>

{{for|the Australian Railway Construction Act of 1884|Railway Construction Act 821}} {{unreferenced|date=May 2008}}The {{nihongo|'''Railway Construction Act'''|鉄道敷設法|Tetsudō Fusetsu-hō''|Law No. 4 of 1892|lead=yes}} was promulgated by the [[Diet of Japan]] on June 21, 1892, and designated government support for a network of thirty-three [[railway]] lines covering most of Japan, with the exception of [[Hokkaidō]]. On April 11, 1922, the Diet amended the law to add an additional network of regional and local routes. Today, these lines form the backbone of the national railway network, [[Japan Railways Group|JR]] (although JR has relinquished control of some of the more minor ones).

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2015}} {{Use Australian English|date=June 2015}} The [[Government of Victoria (Australia)|Victorian Government]]'s '''Act No. 821''', '''Railway Construction Act 1884''', authorised the construction of 59<ref>Some sources give this figure as 66.</ref> new railway lines. Created by the Minister for Railways, [[Thomas Bent]],<ref>http://www.emelbourne.net.au/biogs/EM01222b.htm</ref> and passed on 12 December 1884, it became notorious for the excessive number of inner-city railways it created, and received the nickname "the '''Octopus Act'''". The depression of the 1890s soon rendered many of these lines unviable.
==Implementation== The task of implementing the act fell to [[Richard Speight]], Railway Commissioner at the time,<ref>http://www.adb.online.anu.edu.au/biogs/A060189b.htm</ref> a role created by the [[Victorian Railways Commissioners Act]] of 1883.<ref>http://www.brightoncemetery.com/HistoricInterments/150Names/kibblew.htm</ref>
Beneficiaries of the act included construction engineers such as [[Andrew O'Keefe (engineer)|Andrew O'Keefe]], and politicians such as Thomas Bent himself, who reaped the rewards of commissioning construction in their own electorates.
Construction of the lines was complete by April 1890.<ref>http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article3516141</ref>
By 1892, outrage at the excesses of this construction boom, including a number of "white elephants", led to the sacking of Speight, [[Richard Ford (railway commissioner)|Richard Ford]] and [[A J Agg]], the other commissioners. Then, the [[Railways Act of 1892]], attempted to reverse some of the damage.
==See also== * [[Rail transport in Victoria]]
==Sources== *http://www.parliament.vic.gov.au/onthisday/decade.cfm?d=1880 *http://www.vicrailstations.com/Outer_Circle/Outer_Circle.html *http://www.vrhistory.com/VRMaps/ *http://www.northernbullants.com.au/media/Archives/OurTown/1889TheRailway.html
<references />
==External links== *[http://www.vrhistory.com/VRMaps/Vic1880.pdf Victorian railway map of 1880] *[http://www.vrhistory.com/VRMaps/Vic1890.pdf Victorian railway map of 1890]

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} {{Judicial interpretation}} '''The rule of lenity''' (also called '''the rule of strict construction''') is a principle of [[Criminal law|criminal]] [[statutory interpretation]] that requires a court to apply any unclear or ambiguous law in the manner most favorable to the defendant. It has a long history in the law and has been an important element of the relationship between the courts and legislature, although its role in modern jurisprudence is less clear. ==Overview== {{see|Separation of powers}} Today, determining legislative intent is a critical job that arises from the distinct and separate roles played by the [[judiciary]] and the [[legislature]] in administering justice. [[Court|Judges]] are routinely required to apply the relevant laws and rules passed by the legislature to the decisions they make. There are reasons this can be difficult. For one, laws are intended to apply generally and it would be impossible for the legislature to foresee all the possible situations to which they might apply after their enactment. Second, the manner in which laws are passed, which includes the influence of [[lobbying]] and interest groups, can sometimes obscure their purpose when finally enacted. Finally, the two branches are not allowed to "confer" with one another. Neither is the legislature allowed to add to a law it has already passed in order to affect a court's ruling, nor are the courts allowed to "inquire" as to how a law should be applied in the cases before them. The two institutions have evolved tools to make the job easier. For instance, statutes often contain "definition" sections, which attempt to make plain how the statute should be read. The courts have developed "canons of construction", rules which are intended to guide the manner in which a statute is to be applied. The rule of lenity is one such canon. Implicit in its provisions is the additional [[Burden of proof (law)|burden]] placed on the prosecution in a criminal case and the protection of [[Due process|individual rights]] against the powers of the state. It also furthers the fundamental principle of requiring [[notice]] in criminal law. Individuals should not be punished for their acts when the law fails to communicate to the public that such acts are forbidden. It is intended only to apply to those instances where the court recognizes the existence of more than one interpretation ''and'' where the decision that the court reaches harms or benefits the defendant to some greater or lesser degree. In that case, the rule requires the court to select the interpretation most beneficial (or least detrimental) to the defendant. ==History== The traditional rule, also called the rule of strict construction, arose for a very different purpose in the [[English common law]] than those cited in [[Laws of the United States|U.S. law]]. ===English common law=== Originally, the rule was conceived by English judges trying to limit [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|Parliament]]'s use of the [[Death penalty in the United Kingdom|death penalty]]. When the facts of a case were not expressly described by a law, the court would "strictly construe" it so as to exclude its application to the case in question. A 1547, a law passed that denied [[Benefit of clergy|a lesser sentence]] to first-time offenders convicted of "felonious stealing of Horses, Geldings or Mares" among other offenses. 1 Edw. VIII c.12(X)(3), (1547), {{cite book |last1=Ruffhead |first1=Owen |last2=Adams |first2=John |author-link1=Owen Ruffhead |author-link2=John Adams |date=1763 |title=The statutes at large: from Magna Charta, to the end of the last parliament, 1761. In eight volumes |url=https://archive.org/stream/statutesatlargef02grea#page/394/mode/1up |page=395 |volume=Vol. 2 |location=London |publisher=Mark Basket and his assigns, Mark Woodfall, and William Strahan | access-date=28 September 2017}} The courts interpreted the law as only applying to those convicted of stealing two or more horses and allowed first-offenders who stole one horse to continue to avail themselves of the lesser penalty. The following year, Parliament explicitly addressed the rule's use with the passage of a new law, solely dedicated to horse thievery. They pointed to the prior law's "ambiguous" wording and its construction by the courts. The new law explicitly stated that those convicted of stealing "any Horse, Gelding, or Mare" shall be treated the same as those charged with "stealing two Horses, two Geldings, or two Mares, or any other". 2 & 3 Edw. VIII c.37(X)(3), (1547), {{cite book |last1=Ruffhead |first1=Owen |last2=Adams |first2=John |date=1763 |title=The statutes at large: from Magna Charta, to the end of the last parliament, 1761. In eight volumes |url=https://archive.org/stream/statutesatlargef02grea#page/425/mode/1up |page=426 |volume=Vol. 2 |location=London |publisher=Mark Basket and his assigns, Mark Woodfall, and William Strahan | access-date=28 September 2017}}{{cite book|first=John Hamilton |last= Baker|title=The Oxford History of the Laws of England: 1483-1558|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GWceAPzUrpwC|accessdate=28 September 2017|year=2003|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=London|isbn=978-0-19-825817-9|page=540|chapter=Ch. 6: Criminal Law and Procedure}}{{cite book|first= William |last= Blackstone|author-link=William Blackstone |title=Commentaries on the Laws of England|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mCc0AAAAIAAJ|edition=William Carey Jones|year=1915|publisher=Bancroft-Whitney Company|location=San Francisco|page=154|chapter=Pt.3 Sec.118 (I): Construction of Penal Statutes}} Under the reign of [[George II of Great Britain|George II]], another law concerning first-offenders and livestock was similarly limited by the courts. This time, the act ambiguously referred to "Sheep, or other Cattle." 14 Geo. II c.6(I), (1547), {{cite book |last1=Ruffhead |first1=Owen |last2=Adams |first2=John |date=1765 |title=The statutes at large: from Magna Charta, to the end of the last parliament, 1761. In eight volumes |url=https://archive.org/stream/statutesatlargef06grea#page/409/mode/1up/search/14+George |page=410 |volume=Vol. 6 |location=London |publisher=Mark Basket and his assigns, Mark Woodfall, and William Strahan | access-date=28 September 2017}} Again, the following year, Parliament passed a new "Act to Explain An Act". In it, they expressly spell out that it shall apply to "any Bull, Cow, Ox, Steer, Bullock, Heifer, Calf and Lamb, as well as sheep". ===Early American law=== Laying out the rule's application in the American courts, it was first cited in 1820 by [[Chief Justice]] [[John Marshall]] in ''[[United States v. Wiltberger]]'':
The rule that penal laws are to be construed strictly, is perhaps not much less old than construction itself. It is founded on the tenderness of the law for the rights of individuals; and on the plain principle, that the power of punishment is vested in the legislative, not in the judicial department. ... [T]hough penal laws are to be construed strictly, they are not to be construed so strictly as to defeat the obvious intention of the legislature. The maxim is not to be so applied as to narrow the words of the statute... in their ordinary acceptation, or in which the legislature has obviously used them.... The intention of the legislature is to be collected from the words they employ. Where there is no ambiguity in *the words, there is no room for construction.[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=15837139254241140507&q=united+states+v.+wiltberger&hl=en&as_sdt=6,39&as_vis=1 18 US 76, 95 (Supreme Court 1820)].
===20th century=== After its initial wide acceptance, other canons, such as the [[clear statement rule]] and the [[vagueness doctrine]], have encroached on the rule and its use by the courts. In 1961, [[Felix Frankfurter|Justice Frankfurter]] wrote in ''[[Callanan v. United States]]'', that the rule is for expressing the will of Congress, not protecting defendants from it:
The rule of lenity [is] for resolving an ambiguity, not [creating one].... The rule comes into operation at the end of the process of interpreting what Congress has expressed, not at the beginning as an overriding consideration of being lenient to wrongdoers.[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=10261023883092961366&q=callanan+v+united+states&hl=en&as_sdt=6,39 364 U.S. 587, 596 (Supreme Court 1961)]
==Islamic law== [[Sharia|Islamic law]] has a similar tenet which allows the imposition of [[Hudud|punishments]] only in the absence of "doubt or ambiguity".{{sfnp|Rabb|2011|page=1316-1317}}{{cite magazine |first=Intisar A.|last=Rabb |author-link=Intisar Rabb |title=Islamic Legal Maxims as Substantive Canons of Construction: Ḥudūd-Avoidance in Cases of Doubt |journal=Islamic Law and Society |volume= 17 |pages= 63–125 at 66 |date=2010 |url=http://lawdigitalcommons.bc.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1484&context=lsfp |accessdate=3 October 2017}} ==Modern status== The rule is today seen as an expression of [[legislative supremacy]].{{sfnp|Rabb|2011|page=1305}} It is infrequently cited in contemporary{{clarify|contemporary with what?|date=September 2018}} opinions.{{sfn|Price|2004|page=902}} During oral arguments for the 2016 case, ''[[Lockhart v. United States (2016)|Lockhart v. United States]]'',[https://scholar.google.com/scholar?scidkt=18180785990255627732&as_sdt=2&hl=en 136 S. Ct. 958 (Supreme Court 2016)] Justice [[Antonin Scalia]] ''[[sua sponte]]'' raised the question of the rule's application:
"... what I worry about is the rule of lenity. You have these dueling canons, and you have a rule that when the government sends somebody to jail for 10 years, it has to cross sharp corners. It has to dot every i and cross every t. It has to be clear!"{{cite news| title=Scalia Sticks Up for a Child Pornography Convict |last=Stern |first=Mark Joseph |work=[[Slate.com|Slate]] |date=3 November 2015 |access-date=3 October 2017|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/supreme_court_dispatches/2015/11/supreme_court_lockhart_case_scalia_argues_for_lenity.html}}
In the end, he joined the majority in refusing to apply the rule. 136 S. Ct. 958 at 968 See the dissent by Justices [[Elena Kagan]] and [[Stephen Breyer]]. They expressly support the rule and its use in the case before them (136 S. Ct. at 977). In ''State v. Thonesavanh'', The [[Minnesota Supreme Court]] expressly rejected the position that the rule "...allows a defendant to prevail in every instance in which a criminal statute is ambiguous."[https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=18215598182342264352&hl=en&as_sdt=6,39 State v. Thonesavanh No.A15-2017, pt. III, para. 1 (decided Sep. 6, 2016)] At issue was the question of whether the word "take" as used in the state's law against auto theft[https://www.revisor.mn.gov/statutes/?id=609.52 Minn. Stat. 609.52, subd. 2(a)(17)] required the accused to actually move the vehicle, or, as in the case before them, merely to enter it and lock the doors. The court relied on the doctrine of ''in pari materia'' in holding that the mere "temporary control" of the car was enough under the statue.{{cite news |last=Jones |first=Barbara L. |title=Supreme Court reverses ruling in auto theft that went nowhere |url=http://minnlawyer.com/2017/09/08/supreme-court-reverses-ruling-in-auto-theft-that-went-nowhere/ |date=8 September 2017 |work=Minnesota Lawyer |access-date=3 October 2017}} On the other hand, the [[Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court]] cited the rule in ''Commonwealth vs. Dayton'',[https://scholar.google.com/scholar?scidkt=10722638148962002824&as_sdt=2&hl=en No. SJC-12213, Discussion para. 2 (decided June 1, 2017)] in ruling that the ambiguous language in the state's [[D.U.I.|OUI law]] did not permit a suspect to be held without bail unless they have been convicted three times under the statute, as opposed to merely being ''arrested'' three times.{{cite news |last=Dunn |first=Bob |title=Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court finds OUI law ambiguous |url=http://www.berkshireeagle.com/stories/court-finds-oui-law-ambiguous,510169 |date=11 June 2017 |work=The Berkshire Eagle |access-date=3 October 2017}} ===State codification=== The states of Florida and Ohio have [[Codification (law)|codified]] the rule.{{sfn|Price|2004|page=902}} The [[Florida Statutes|Florida statute]] states that the code "shall be strictly construed; when the language is susceptible of differing constructions, it shall be construed most favorably to the accused."{{cite web|work= Florida Stat. Ann. |title = Sec. 775.021 |url=http://leg.state.fl.us/Statutes/index.cfm?App_mode=Display_Statute&Search_String=&URL=0700-0799/0775/Sections/0775.021.html|access-date=3 October 2017 |date=}}{{sfn|Price|2004|page=902}} The [[Ohio Revised Code|Ohio law]] states simply that offenses and penalties shall be "strictly construed against the state and liberally construed in favor of the accused."{{cite web |work= Ohio Rev. Code |title= Sec. 2901.04 |url=http://codes.ohio.gov/orc/2901.04v1 |access-date=3 October 2017}} A greater number of states, however, have statutorily eliminated the rule.{{sfn|Price|2004|page=903}} ==See also== *[[Ex post facto law]] ==References== ===Footnotes=== {{reflist}} ===Works cited=== {{refbegin}} * {{cite magazine |first=Intisar A.|last=Rabb |author-link=Intisar Rabb |title=The Islamic Rule of Lenity |journal=Vanderbilt Journal of Transnational Law |volume=44 |issue=5 |date=2011 |pages=1299-1351 |url=http://lawdigitalcommons.bc.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1484&context=lsfp |accessdate=3 October 2017}} * {{cite magazine |first=Zachary|last=Price |title=The Rule of Lenity as a Rule of Structure |journal=Fordham Law Review |volume=72 |date=2004 |url=https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=2359691 |accessdate=3 October 2017}} {{refend}} [[Category:Common law]] [[Category:Statutory law]] [[Category:English criminal law]] [[Category:Criminal law]]
